creator: abatko@cs.mcgill.ca
text:
Hello. I am experiencing a strange behaviour from SSI's ``#include virtual'' element/attribute. The following piece of HTML/SSI fails to include (load) the intended html file (header.html), yet it does display the date (indicating that ssi is working).

hello

Hello, today is

bye

Besides the error message on the webpage [an error occurred while processing this directive], there is also a log message sent to httpd-error.log: File does not exist: /u16/ugrad/guide/public_html/common/header.htm Yes, the 'l' is missing, whereas it does appear in the file name in the code above. I copied common/header.html to common/header.htm, and added some text to header.htm to distinguish it from header.html. Upon reloading the page (which calls for header.html), the file header.htm is loaded instead. My httpd.conf file does not contain .htm extensions - only .html ones. I have the directive XBitHack set to 'on'.

Interesting.  Does this problem persist in the latest version (2.0.40)? 
I don't remember seeing any similar reports.
creator: slive@apache.org

text: Thank you for replying.  Yes - this is still a problem in 2.0.40.

Moving the <!--#include virtual... line to another place in the file
did NOT help.

Turning XBitHack off (by using the option "off") and changing
the extention to .shtml did NOT help either.

I also tried uncommenting XBitHack altogether, to no avail.

Finally I changed the extension to .html and placed the following line
in a world readable .htaccess file (also to no avail).

AddHandler server-parsed .html


As for what OS I'm using:  FreeBSD 4.6-RELEASE-p2.  But don't you see
that in the neat little webpage description of the bug?  Or do you not
use web-based bug tracking system?  Anyway, thanks for looking into this.

creator: info@orangexl.com

text:
The core of the breakage is that the last char of 
the filename was lost (ssi page asked for common/header.html
but Apache tried to open common/header.htm instead).

This is the same as PR 14147, 10687, 10236 and is already
fixed.  The fix was after 2.0.43 so wait for 2.0.44.

Thanks for your report, and thanks for using Apache!
